p: Marine ecosystems and fisheries provide a crucial foundation for human well-being and development, yielding 81.5 million tons of catch in 2014, valued at over USD 90 billion [ 1]. For many low-income food-deficit countries (LIFDCs) and local communities in developing countries, near-shore marine fisheries also provide a crucial source of micronutrients, which are necessary for early childhood development and influence long-term public health outcomes [ 2][ 3]. Simultaneously, demand for fish has been growing, with per capita annual consumption more than doubling since the 1960s, rendering the trade in marine foodstuffs a potential motor for development [ 1].
